identificationModule.briefTitle: Effect of Robotised Gait Training on Dynamic Balance, Symmetry and Push-off in Persons After Stroke
identificationModule.officialTitle: Effect of Robotised Gait Training on Dynamic Balance, Symmetry and Push-off in Persons After Stroke

leadSponsor.name: University Rehabilitation Institute, Republic of Slovenia

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Rehabilitation robotics is increasingly used because it enables the patients to practice a wide array of movements. Dynamic balance training is essential for gait rehabilitation and robotised devices enhance repeatability, objectivity and precision of such training combined with monitoring and recording of kinematic and kinetic data. The aim of the study is to explore the effect of robot-assisted gait training on dynamic balance, symmetry and take-off in patients after stroke. The investigators will conduct a randomised intervention study where one group will receive visual feedback on gait status and the other group will receive kinetically-assisted training using a robotised device in addition to the visual feedback.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Gait training will start 3 weeks after admission to inpatient rehabilitation. It will last for 3 weeks, 5 times per week, 30 minutes per day. The first few sessions with the robotic device will serve to familiarise the patient with the BART device and training conditions. Further details are described in the Arms and Interventions section.

armGroups.label: Controls
interventionNames: Device: Standard gait training on BART without pelvic perturbations

armGroups.label: Experimental
interventionNames: Device: Robotised gait training with BART with pelvic perturbations

interventions.name: Standard gait training on BART without pelvic perturbations
interventions.description: The Balance Assisted Robot on Treadmill (BART) enables various types of gait training on treadmill with visual feedback. It interfaces to the pelvis of the walking subject in an actuated and admittance-controlled manner, thus providing transparent haptic interaction with negligible power transfer.

interventions.name: Robotised gait training with BART with pelvic perturbations
interventions.description: In addition to the standard gait training, the BART will deliver perturbations in the forward/backward and left/right direction.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in postural stability during walking
primaryOutcomes.description: Assessed using the Functional Gait Assessment (FGA) scale. The scale scores range from 0 to 30, with higher scores indicating less impairment.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Assessment before and after the 3-week training programme

secondaryOutcomes.description: Assessed using the Functional Ambulation Categories (FAC) scale. The FAC is a 6-point scale (0-5), with higher category indicating better walking ability.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Assessment before and after the 3-week training programme

secondaryOutcomes.description: Assessed using the Motor subscale of the Functional Independence Measure (FIM). FIM Motor subscale scores range from 13 to 91, with higher scores indicating better functional independence.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Assessment before and after the 3-week training programme

secondaryOutcomes.description: Assessed using the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test. Longer TUG times indicate worse mobility (and thus higher fall risk).
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Assessment before and after the 3-week training programme

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in ability to change directions while stepping
secondaryOutcomes.description: Assessed using the Four Square Step Test (FSST). The FSST is timed, with longer times indicating worse ability.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Assessment before and after the 3-week training programme

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in walking speed over a short distance
secondaryOutcomes.description: Assessed using the 10 Meter Walk Test (10MWT)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Assessment before and after the 3-week training programme

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in walking speed over a long distance
secondaryOutcomes.description: Assessed using the 6 Minute Walk Test (6MWT)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Assessment before and after the 3-week training programme

otherOutcomes.measure: Changes in kinesiological characteristics of gait
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: Assessment before and after the 3-week training programme
